{{small|(first observed only)}} | discovered = 30 November 2010 | mpc_name = {{mp|2010 WC|9}} | alt_names = ZJ99C60 | pronounced = | named_after = | mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[Apollo asteroid|Apollo]]  | epoch = 23 March 2018 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458200.5) | uncertainty = 0 | observation_arc = 7.45 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (2,721 d) | aphelion = 1.3797 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 0.7784 AU | semimajor = 1.0791 AU | eccentricity = 0.2786 | period = 1.12 yr (409 d) | mean_anomaly = 251.06[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.8793|sup=ms}} / day | inclination = 17.994° | asc_node = 54.655° | arg_peri = 273.53° | moid = 0.00138 AU (0.5454 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|LD]]) | venus_moid = {{convert|0.158|AU|km|abbr=on|lk=off}} | mean_diameter = {{val|60|-|130|ul=m}}
{{val|60|u=m}} {{small|(est. at [[Geometric albedo|0.20]])}}
{{val|130|u=m}} {{small|(est. at [[Geometric albedo|0.04]])}} | rotation = 8–20 minutes | albedo = | spectral_type = | abs_magnitude = 23.5 }} '''{{mp|2010 WC|9}}''', unofficially designated {{mp|ZJ99C60}}, is a sub-kilometer [[Near-Earth object|near-Earth asteroid]] of the [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo group]], approximately {{convert|100|m||abbr=off|sp=us}} in diameter. First observed for eleven days by the [[Catalina Sky Survey]] in 2010, the asteroid was recovered in May 2018 during its sub-lunar close encounter with Earth. == First observation and recovery == {{mp|2010 WC|9}} was first observed by astronomers with the [[Catalina Sky Survey]] on 30 November 2010 with a 1-day [[observation arc]] and was observed through 10 December 2010. By 10 December 2010 the asteroid was more than 24 million kilometers from Earth at [[apparent magnitude]] 21.8 and was becoming too faint to be practical to track. The preliminary 10-day observation arc generated a [[Confidence region|line of variation]] roughly 15 million km long for May 2018 that did not intersect Earth's orbit and thus was not a 2018 impact threat. The 10-day observation arc showed the asteroid would pass about {{convert|0.026|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} from Earth around late 14 May 2018. The asteroid was recovered on 8 May 2018 when it was 8 million kilometers from Earth and given the temporary NEOCP designation ZJ99C60. It was removed from the [[Sentry (monitoring system)|Sentry Risk Table]] on 10 May 2018 and is not an impact threat for the next 100 years or more. The asteroid now has a secure 7-year observation arc. == Orbit and classification == {{mp|2010 WC|9}} is an [[Apollo asteroid]], the largest dynamical group of [[near-Earth object]]s with nearly 10,000 known members. It orbits the Sun at a distance of 0.78–1.4 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] once every 13 months (409 days; [[semi-major axis]] of 1.08 AU). Its orbit has an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.28 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 18[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the [[ecliptic]]. Using an [[Epoch (astronomy)|epoch]] of 23 March 2018, the object had a [[minimum orbital intersection distance]] with Earth of {{convert |0.00138 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=off |sigfig=3 |order=flip}}, or 0.55 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distances]] (LD). == 2018 approach == {{multiple image |direction = vertical |align = left |width = 225 |image1 = 2010_WC9-2018sky.png |image2 = 2010_WC9-2018flyby.png |footer = Flyby in 2018: geocentric trajectory in the sky (top) and flyby from north to south, shown with hourly motion (bottom) }} On 15 May 2018, 22:05 [[Universal Time|UT]], the asteroid approached Earth at just over 0.5 LD, the closest approach of this asteroid in nearly 300 years.. It was expected to reach [[apparent magnitude]] +11 at closest approach, bright enough to be seen in a small telescope if you have a custom [[ephemeris]] for your location. At closest approach, it was best seen from the Southern hemisphere such as South Africa and southern South America. The asteroid passed Earth going {{convert|12.81|km/s|mph|abbr=on}}. This was the third closest approach ever observed by an asteroid with [[Absolute_magnitude#Solar_System_bodies_(H)|absolute magnitude]] (H) brighter than 24. {{Large near earth asteroid flybys 1LD}} == Physical characteristics == === Diameter === As the asteroid has not been directly resolved by telescope, its diameter can only be estimated based on the distance and brightness. Based on a generic magnitude-to-diameter conversion, it is estimated to measure between 60–130 meters in diameter, for an [[absolute magnitude]] of 23.5, and an assumed [[astronomical albedo|albedo]] of 0.04–0.20. == Numbering and naming == As of 2018, this [[minor planet]] has neither been numbered nor [[List of named minor planets (alphabetical)|named]] by the [[Minor Planet Center]]. == See {{short description|Ancient Greek myth}} {{otheruses}} {{Redirect|Acis||ACIS (disambiguation)}}[[File:Guillemot - Acis and Galatea, 1827.jpg|thumb|''The Loves of Acis and Galatea'' by Alexandre Charles Guillemot (1827)]] {{Greek myth (sea)}} '''Acis and Galatea''' is a story from [[Greek mythology]] that originally appeared in [[Ovid]]'s ''[[Metamorphoses (poem)|Metamorphoses]]''. The story tells of the love between the mortal Acis and the [[Nereid]] (sea-nymph) Galatea; when the jealous [[Cyclops]] [[Polyphemus]] kills Acis, Galatea transforms her lover into an immortal river spirit. The episode was made the subject of poems, operas, paintings, and statues in the [[Renaissance]] and after.
==Mythology== Galatea (Γαλάτεια; "she who is milk-white"), daughter of [[Nereus]] and [[Doris (mythology)|Doris]], was a sea-nymph anciently attested in the work of both [[Homer]] and [[Hesiod]], where she is described as the fairest and most beloved of the 50 [[Nereids]].<ref>Hesiod, ''[[Theogony]]''; Homer, ''[[Iliad]]''.</ref> In [[Ovid]]'s ''[[Metamorphoses]]'' she appears as the beloved of Acis, the son of [[Faunus]] and the [[naiad|river-nymph]] Symaethis, daughter of the River [[Simeto|Symaethus]]. When a jealous rival, the Sicilian [[Cyclops]] [[Polyphemus]], killed him with a boulder, Galatea then turned his blood into the Sicilian River [[Acireale|Acis]], of which he became the spirit.<ref>Ovid, ''Metamorphoses'' [http://www.poetryintranslation.com/PITBR/Latin/Metamorph13.htm#_Toc64105850 xiii.750-68].</ref> This version of the tale occurs nowhere earlier and may be a fiction invented by Ovid, "suggested by the manner in which the little river springs forth from under a rock".<ref>{{Citation | last = Schmitz | first = Leonhard | author-link = Leonhard Schmitz | contribution = Acis | editor-last = Smith | editor-first = William | title = [[Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology]] | volume = 1 | pages = 13 | place = Boston, MA | year = 1867 | contribution-url = http://www.ancientlibrary.com/smith-bio/0022.html }}</ref> According to [[Athenaeus]], ca 200 CE,<ref>[[Athenaeus]], ''Deipnosophistae'' [http://www.attalus.org/old/athenaeus1.html#6 1.6e]</ref> the story was first concocted by [[Philoxenus of Cythera]] as a political satire against the Sicilian tyrant [[Dionysius I of Syracuse]], whose favourite concubine, Galatea, shared her name with the nymph. Others claim the story was invented to explain the presence of a shrine dedicated to Galatea on Mount Etna.<ref>Scholiast on Theocritus' ''Idyll VI'' quoting the historian Duris and the poet Philoxenus of Cythera</ref>
==Cultural references== [[File:French Empire mantel clock.jpg|thumb|left|An 1822 [[French Empire mantel clock]] depicting Galatea. The design on its frieze is based on Rafael's fresco]]
===Literary and operatic===
During [[Renaissance]] and [[Baroque]] times the story emerged once more as a popular theme. In Spain, [[Luis de Góngora y Argote]] wrote the much-admired narrative poem, ''Fábula de [[Polifemo]] y Galatea'', published in 1627. It is particularly noted for its depiction of landscape and for the sensual description of the love of Acis and Galatea.<ref>{{cite book|title=Selected Poems of Luis de Góngora|work=University of Chicago|year=2008|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=M73JAsBiFxoC&lpg=PA173&dq=Polyphemus%20poem&pg=PA173#v=onepage&q=Polyphemus%20poem&f=false|page=176ff}}</ref> It was written in homage to an earlier and rather shorter narrative with the same title by Luis Carillo y Sotomayor (1611)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biblioteca-antologica.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/CARRILLO-DE-SOTOMAYOR-F%C3%A1bula-de-Acis-y-Galatea-YA.pdf|format=PDF|title=Selected Poems of Luis de Góngora|website=biblioteca-antologica.org|access-date=2013-09-02|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130512224721/http://www.biblioteca-antologica.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/CARRILLO-DE-SOTOMAYOR-F%C3%A1bula-de-Acis-y-Galatea-YA.pdf|archive-date=2013-05-12|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The story was also given operatic treatment in the very popular [[zarzuela]] of [[Antoni Lliteres Carrió]] (1708). The atmosphere here is lighter and enlivened by the inclusion of the clowns Momo and Tisbe.
In France, [[Jean-Baptiste Lully]] devoted his opera [[Acis et Galatée]] (1686) to their love.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prestoclassical.co.uk/r/DG%2BArchiv/E4534972|title=Presto Classical - Lully: Acis et Galatée - DG Archiv: E4534972 (download) - Buy online|work=prestoclassical.co.uk}}</ref> Described by him as a pastoral-heroic work, it depicts a love triangle between the three main characters - Acis, Galatea, and Poliphème. Poliphème murders Acis out of jealousy, but Acis is revived and turned into a river by [[Neptune (mythology)|Neptune]]. In Italy [[Giovanni Bononcini]]'s one-act opera ''Polifemo'' followed in 1703.<ref name="youtube">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RVaNW5ib6N8|title=Martina Bovet: Dove sei, dove t'ascondi; G. B. Bononcini (Polifemo) - YouTube|publisher=youtube.com|accessdate=2014-09-12}}</ref> Shortly afterwards [[George Frideric Handel]] was working in that country and composed the cantata ''[[Aci, Galatea e Polifemo]]'' (1708), laying as much emphasis on the part of Polifemo as on the lovers. Written in Italian, Polifemo's deep bass solo ''Fra l'ombre e gl'orrori'' (From horrid shades) establishes his character from the start.<ref name="youtube2">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9c82JE9GK8I|title=Aci, Galatea e Polifemo - Fra l'ombre e gl'orrori - YouTube|publisher=youtube.com|accessdate=2014-09-12}}</ref>
After Handel's move to England, he gave the story a new treatment in his [[pastoral]] opera ''[[Acis and Galatea (Handel)|Acis and Galatea]]'' with an English libretto provided by [[John Gay]].<ref>The text is on the [http://opera.stanford.edu/iu/libretti/acis.htm Stanford University site] and there is a complete performance on [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vew-CeKW-SU YouTube]</ref> Initially composed in 1718, the work went through many revisions and was later to be given updated orchestrations by both [[Mozart]] and [[Mendelssohn]]. As a pastoral work where Polyphemus plays only a minor, though decisive part, it largely centres on the two lovers. In Austria later in the century, [[Joseph Haydn]] composed ''Acide e Galatea'' (1763).<ref>Brief excerpts at [http://www.classicalarchives.com/work/126417.html Classical Archives]</ref> Designed for an imperial wedding, it was given a happier ending centred on the transformation scene after the murder of Acis as the pair declare their undying love.<ref>Rebecca Green, "Representing the Aristocracy", in ''Haydn and his world'', Princeton University 1997, [https://books.google.com/books?id=omPuBn8pTFUC&lpg=PA167&ots=1GDMhp5YXs&dq=Acide%20e%20Galatea%20%22Haydn%22&pg=PA167#v=onepage&q=Acide%20e%20Galatea%20%22Haydn%22&f=false pp.167-8]</ref>
===Painting=== <gallery mode="packed-hover"> File:Édouard Zier - Acis et Galathée se cachant de Polyphème.jpg|Acis and Galatea hiding from Polyphemus by Édouard Zier (1877) File:Acis LACMA M.88.91.382m.jpg|Acis by Philip Galle (1586) File:Atis and Galathea (Pompeo Batoni) - Nationalmuseum - 23711.tif|Atis and Galathea by Pompeo Batoni (1761) File:Nicolas Poussin - Acis et Galatée.jpg|Acis and Galatea by Nicolas Poussin (circa 1629-1630) File:Nicolas Bertin-Acis et Galathée.jpg|Acis and Galatea by Nicolas Bertin File:Acis und Galatea (van Schuppen).jpg|Acis und Galatea by Jacob van Schuppen (circa 1730) File:François Perrier - Acis, Galatea, and Polyphemus - WGA17206.jpg|Acis, Galatea, and Polyphemus by François Perrier (1645 and 1650) File:Claude Lorrain 001.jpg|Coastal landscape with Acis and Galatea by Claude Lorrain (1657) File:Michel corneille acis et galatée.JPG|Acis and Galatea by Michel Corneille File:Nicolas Poussin - Paysage avec Polyphème.jpg|Landscape with Polyphemus by Nicolas Poussin </gallery>Paintings featuring Acis and Galatea can be grouped according to their themes. Most notably the story takes place within a pastoral landscape in which the figures are almost incidental. This is particularly so in Nicolas Poussin's ''Landscape with Polyphemus'' (1649)([[Hermitage Museum]]) and [[Claude Lorrain]]'s seaside landscape ([[Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister|Dresden]]) of 1657, in both of which the lovers play a minor part in the foreground. In an earlier painting by Poussin ([[National Gallery of Ireland]], 1630) the couple is among several embracing figures in the foreground, shielded from view of Polyphemus, who is playing his flute higher up the slope.
In all of these Polyphemus is somewhere in the background, but many others feature Galatea alone, as in [[Perino del Vaga]]'s painting of her being drawn by sea beasts over the waves while riding on a seashell.<ref>http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-yKTcOgwlx0U/TxqpsTcifiI/AAAAAAAALN4/D5PDymRH16k/s1600/Galatea.jpg</ref> Generally, though, the nymph is carried through the sea by adoring attendants in paintings generally titled ''The Triumph of Galatea'', of which the most renowned treatment is by [[Galatea (Raphael)|Raphael]]. In general these follow the 3rd-century description given of such a painting by [[Philostratus the Younger]] in his ''[[Imagines (work by Philostratus)|Imagines]]'':<ref>[http://www.theoi.com/Text/PhilostratusElder2B.html#18 2.18], translation by Arthur Fairbanks, (Loeb 1931)</ref> {{quote|The nymph sports on the peaceful sea, driving a team of four dolphins yoked together and working in harmony; and maiden-daughters of [[Triton (mythology)|Triton]], Galatea's servants, guide them, curving them in if they try to do anything mischievous or contrary to the rein. She holds over her heads against the wind a light scarf of sea-purple to provide a shade for herself and a sail for her chariot, and from it a kind of radiance falls upon her forehead and her head, though no white more charming than the bloom on her cheek; her hair is not tossed by the breeze, for it is so moist that it is proof against the wind. And lo, her right elbow stands out and her white forearm is bent back, while she rests her fingers on her delicate shoulder, and her arms are gently rounded, and her breasts project, nor yet is beauty lacking in her thigh. Her foot, with the graceful part that ends in it, is painted as on the sea and it lightly touches the water as if it were the rudder guiding her chariot. Her eyes are wonderful, for they have a kind of distant look that travels as far as the sea extends.}} In those cases where the rejected lover Polyphemus appears somewhere ashore, the division between them is emphasised by their being identified with their respective elements, sea, and land. Typical examples of this were painted by [[Francois Perrier (painter)|Francois Perrier]],<ref>http://www.wga.hu/art/p/perrier/acisgala.jpg</ref> [[Giovanni Lanfranco]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artclon.com/paintings/galatea-and-polyphemus_29085.html|title=Giovanni Lanfranco Galatea and Polyphemus Painting Reproduction On Artclon For Sale - Buy Art Reproductions Galatea and Polyphemus|work=artclon.com}}</ref> and [[Jean-Baptiste van Loo]].
Sensual portrayals of the lovers embracing in a landscape were provided by French painters especially, as in those by [[Charles de La Fosse]] (c. 1700), [[Jean-François de Troy]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/lot/jean-francois-de-troy-acis-and-galatea-4684830-details.aspx?intObjectID=4684830|title=Jean-François de Troy (Paris 1679-1752 Rome)|author=Christie?s|work=christies.com}}</ref> and Alexandre Charles Guillemot (1827).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-athenaeum.org/art/full.php?ID=22030|title=The Athenaeum - The Loves of Acis and Galatea (Alexandre Charles Guillemot - )|work=the-athenaeum.org}}</ref> Polyphemus lurks in the background of these and in the example by De Troy his presence plainly distresses Galatea. Other French examples by [[Antoine Jean Gros]] (1833)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bonzasheila.com/art/archives/feb06/09.html|title=Acis And Galatea by AntoineJean Gros, 1833. BonzaSheila Presents The Art Of Love Archives For February, 2006|author=ALL|work=bonzasheila.com}}</ref> and [[Édouard François Zier|Édouard Zier]] (1877) show the lovers hiding in a cave and peering anxiously out at him.
They anticipate the tragic moment when he looms menacingly over the pair, having discovered the truth they have tried to conceal. The threat is as apparent in [[Jean-Francois de Troy]]'s softly outlined 18th-century vision<ref name="tribe">{{cite web|url=http://tribes.tribe.net/b9b544af-89e5-4aa7-8dec-c917f83c3bd7/photos/ce5f648c-2c00-4f13-9147-55c24bbbbc1b|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202200306/http://tribes.tribe.net/b9b544af-89e5-4aa7-8dec-c917f83c3bd7/photos/ce5f648c-2c00-4f13-9147-55c24bbbbc1b |archive-date=2014-02-02 |dead-url=yes|title=polyphemus and Acis and Galatea.gif - tribe.net|accessdate=2014-09-12}}</ref> as it is in [[Odilon Redon]]'s almost Surrealist painting of 1900. The brooding atmosphere in these suggests the violent action which is to follow. That had been portrayed in earlier paintings of Polyphemus casting a rock at the fleeing lovers, such as those by [[Annibale Carracci]],<ref name="wga">http://www.wga.hu/art/c/carracci/annibale/farnese/farnese4.jpg</ref> {{Interlanguage link multi|Auger Lucas|fr}}<ref name="gouv">{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/Wave/image/joconde/0640/m507704_02-014751_p.jpg|title=Wave/image/joconde/0640/m507704_02-014751_p|publisher=culture.gouv.fr|accessdate=2014-09-12}}</ref> and [[Carle van Loo]].<ref name="1st-art-gallery">{{cite web|url=http://www.1st-art-gallery.com/%28after%29-Loo,-Carle-Van/Polyphemus-Attacking-Acis-And-Galatea.html|title=Polyphemus attacking Acis and Galatea (after) Loo, Carle van | Oil Painting Reproduction | 1st-Art-Gallery.com|publisher=1st-art-gallery.com|accessdate=2014-09-12}}</ref>
===Sculpture=== <gallery mode="packed-hover"> File:Parc de Versailles, Bosquet des Dômes, Acis, Jean-Baptiste Tuby 02.jpg|Acis playing the flute by [[Jean-Baptiste Tuby]] File:Parc de Versailles, Bosquet des Dômes, Galatée, Jean-Baptiste Tuby 04.jpg|Galatea in the [[Gardens of Versailles]] File:Galatée et Acis.JPG|The lovers embrace on the [[Medici Fountain]], Paris File:Hochzeitszug Elfenbein um 1660-1680.jpg|The lovers drawn over the sea, 17th-century German ivory carving File:Galatea Vase LACMA M.78.27 (2 of 5).jpg|An Italian vase decorated with the Triumph of Galatea File:Schwetzingen Schlosspark Skulpturen 18.jpg|[[Gabriël Grupello]]'s statue at [[Schwetzingen Palace]] File:Galatea-Peterhof.jpg|Nicola Michetti's statue at the [[Peterhof Palace]] File:Galateabrunnen2.JPG|Galatea at the head of the {{Interlanguage link multi|Galatea water well|de|3=Galateabrunnen (Stuttgart)}}, Stuttgart </gallery>
Statues of Galatea, sometimes in the company of Acis, began to be made in Europe from the 17th century. There is a fanciful description of a fountain that incorporates them both in [[John Barclay (poet)|John Barclay]]'s Latin novel ''Argenis'', dating from 1621: {{quote|Being drawn to the top of the fountain, the water passed through many pipes in various forms, then falling into the cistern beneath, it boiled with the force of its falling and waxed green like the sea. In the midst whereof, Galatea, as in the sea, bewailed her newly dead Acis, who lay on the shore, and as if he now began to be dissolved into a river, he sent forth two streams, one at his mouth, the other at his wound.<ref>{{cite book |first=John |last=Barkley |title=Argenis (Mark Riley and Dorothy Pritchard Huber's translation) |location=Assen NL |year= 2004 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8ySgLF4nkmAC&lpg=PA155&dq=fountain%20Galatea%20-Pygmalion&pg=PA155#v=onepage&q=fountain%20Galatea%20-Pygmalion&f=false |page=155}}</ref>}} An actual statue by a pool in the public gardens of [[Acireale]], the Sicilian town where the transformation of Acis is supposed to have taken place, is less ingenious. He lies beneath the boulder that has killed him while Galatea crouches to one side, an arm raised to heaven in supplication.<ref name="blogspot">http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-kThEbQGMmBk/TzGUDIvSurI/AAAAAAABC0g/I-28O8ANL4I/s1600/Marble+statue+in+the+garden+publics+of+Acireale,+Sicily+-+Tutt%27Art@.jpg|title=-kThEbQGMmBk/TzGUDIvSurI/AAAAAAABC0g/I-28O8ANL4I/s1600/Marble+statue+in+the+garden+publics+of+Acireale,+Sicily+-+Tutt%27Art@</ref>
French sculptors have also been responsible for some memorable statues. There are a pair by [[Jean-Baptiste Tuby]] in the Bosquet des Dômes in the [[Gardens of Versailles|Versailles]] gardens. Acis leans on a rock, casually playing the flute, as the half-clad Galatea comes upon him with hands lifted in surprise (1667–75). A similar gesture is displayed in the statue of her alone in the fountain to the right of the great staircase at [[Chantilly, Oise#Château de Chantilly|Château de Chantilly]]. The lovers are portrayed together as part of the Medici Fountain in the [[Luxembourg Garden]] in Paris. Designed by [[Auguste Ottin]] in 1866, the marble group embrace inside a grotto while above them is crouched a huge Polyphemus in weathered bronze, peering down in jealousy.
Many other statues feature Galatea alone, but there is a complication. Some time after the Renaissance, the same name was given to [[Pygmalion (mythology)|Pygmalion]]'s animated statue and one has to distinguish between representations of her and of the nymph Galatea. One pointer is given by the introduction of features mentioned in the description of the nymph by Philostratus that is quoted above. These include one hand raised and holding a billowing scarf; sea imagery, including shells, dolphins and tritons; and often the fact that the statue is incorporated into a fountain. In the work by Gabriel de Grupello in the castle park at [[Schwetzingen]], the triton at Galatea's feet holds up a garland threaded with shells and pearls. The Galatea in the grounds of [[Tsarskoye Selo]] in Russia has sea pearls threaded into her hair. There is also a statue of her by [[Nicola Michetti]] that forms part of the cascade at the [[Peterhof Palace]] in [[St Petersburg]].
The nymph reclines on a large shell carried by tritons in the 18th-century fountain at the Villa Borromeo Visconti Litta in [[Milan]]. It is on the back of a dolphin that she reclines in the statue by the 19th-century Italian sculptor Leopoldo Ansiglioni (1832–1894). There are two versions of this, one at the centre of a fish pool in the East House of the [[University of Greenwich]]'s Winter Gardens,<ref name="flickr">{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/50780708@N02/8368854354/lightbox|title=Galatea | Flickr - Photo Sharing!|publisher=flickr.com|accessdate=2014-09-12}}</ref> and a later copy installed at [[Hearst Castle]] in California.<ref name="pbase">{{cite web|url=http://www.pbase.com/rgardner/image/87228231|title=Hearst Castle Statue - Galatea on a Dolphin by Leopoldo Ansiglioni photo - Rich Gardner photos at pbase.com|publisher=pbase.com|accessdate=2014-09-12}}</ref> In this, one of the arms bent back to support her head is encircled by the dolphin's tail. There is also a German fountain by [[Karl Friedrich Moest]] now installed in [[Karlsruhe]] in which Galatea sits on the back of a triton. Over her head she balances the huge shell from which the water pours. Another statue was erected at the head of an impressive cascade in [[Stuttgart]]'s Eugenplatz.<ref>http://img.marcopolo.de/api/content/images/0/20/5n/hk/yzph/photo-1606191.jpg</ref> A work of Otto Rieth (1858–1911) dating from 1890, it features the nymph crowned with seaweed and surging up from the dolphin and young [[cupid#Cupid and dolphins|cupids]] playing at her feet.
In the applied arts, three-dimensional representations of Raphael's triumph theme were often incorporated into artifacts for aristocratic use and were painted on [[Maiolica|majolica]] ware.
==Notes== {{reflist}}

{{SmithDGRBM|title= Acis}}

{{authority control}}

page.title: Ad Hoc Working Group on Further Commitments for Annex I Parties under the Kyoto Protocol

revision.text:
'''Aerobic fermentation''' is a metabolic process by which cells metabolize sugars via fermentation in the presence of oxygen and occurs through the repression of normal respiratory metabolism (also referred to as the [[crabtree effect]] in yeast).<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=De Deken|first=R. H.|date=1966|title=The Crabtree Effect: A Regulatory System in Yeast|url=|journal=J. Gen. Microbiol.|volume=44|pages=149–156|doi=10.1099/00221287-44-2-149|pmid=5969497}}</ref> This phenomenon is fairly rare and is primarily observed in yeasts.<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last=Piškur|first=Jure|last2=Rozpędowska|first2=Elżbieta|last3=Polakova|first3=Silvia|last4=Merico|first4=Annamaria|last5=Compagno|first5=Concetta|date=2006-04-01|title=How did Saccharomyces evolve to become a good brewer?|url=http://www.cell.com/article/S0168952506000333/abstract|journal=Trends in Genetics|language=English|volume=22|issue=4|pages=183–186|doi=10.1016/j.tig.2006.02.002|issn=0168-9525|pmid=16499989}}</ref> Aerobic fermentation evolved independently in at least three yeast lineages (''[[Saccharomyces]]'', ''[[Dekkera]]'', ''[[Schizosaccharomyces]]'').<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Dashko|first=Sofia|last2=Zhou|first2=Nerve|last3=Compagno|first3=Concetta|last4=Piškur|first4=Jure|date=2014-09-01|title=Why, when, and how did yeast evolve alcoholic fermentation?|url=http://femsyr.oxfordjournals.org/content/14/6/826|journal=FEMS Yeast Research|language=en|volume=14|issue=6|pages=826–832|doi=10.1111/1567-1364.12161|issn=1567-1364|pmc=4262006|pmid=24824836}}</ref> It has also been observed in plant pollen,<ref name=":2" /> trypanosomatids,<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Cazzulo|first=Juan José|date=1992|title=Aerobic fermentation of glucose by trypanosomatids|url=|journal=FASEB|doi=|pmid=1397837|volume=6|pages=3153–61}}</ref> mutated ''E. coli'',<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Portnoy|first=Vasiliy A.|last2=Herrgård|first2=Markus J.|last3=Palsson|first3=Bernhard Ø.|date=2008|title=Aerobic Fermentation of D-Glucose by an Evolved Cytochrome Oxidase-Deficient Escherichia coli Strain|journal=Appl. Environ. Microbiol.|volume=74|pages=7561–7569|doi=10.1128/AEM.00880-08|pmid=18952873|pmc=2607145}}</ref> and tumor cells.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Alfarouk|first=Khalid O.|last2=Verduzco|first2=Daniel|last3=Rauch|first3=Cyril|last4=Muddathir|first4=Abdel Khalig|last5=Adil|first5=H. H. Bashir|last6=Elhassan|first6=Gamal O.|last7=Ibrahim|first7=Muntaser E.|last8=David Polo Orozco|first8=Julian|last9=Cardone|first9=Rosa Angela|date=2014-01-01|title=Glycolysis, tumor metabolism, cancer growth and dissemination. A new pH-based etiopathogenic perspective and therapeutic approach to an old cancer question|journal=Oncoscience|volume=1|issue=12|pages=777–802|issn=2331-4737|pmc=4303887|pmid=25621294|doi=10.18632/oncoscience.109}}</ref> Crabtree-positive yeasts will respire when grown with very low concentrations of glucose or when grown on most other carbohydrate sources.<ref name=":0" /> The Crabtree effect is a regulatory system whereby respiration is repressed by fermentation, except in low sugar conditions.<ref name=":0" /> When ''[[Saccharomyces cerevisiae]]'' is grown below the sugar threshold and undergoes a respiration metabolism, the fermentation pathway is still fully expressed,<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Hagman|first=Arne|last2=Säll|first2=Torbjörn|last3=Compagno|first3=Concetta|last4=Piskur|first4=Jure|title=Yeast "Make-Accumulate-Consume" Life Strategy Evolved as a Multi-Step Process That Predates the Whole Genome Duplication|url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0068734|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=8|issue=7|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0068734|pmc=3711898|pmid=23869229|pages=e68734|bibcode=2013PLoSO...868734H}}</ref> while the respiration pathway is only expressed relative to the sugar availability.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Baumann|first=Kristin|last2=Carnicer|first2=Marc|last3=Dragosits|first3=Martin|last4=Graf|first4=Alexandra B|last5=Stadlmann|first5=Johannes|last6=Jouhten|first6=Paula|last7=Maaheimo|first7=Hannu|last8=Gasser|first8=Brigitte|last9=Albiol|first9=Joan|date=2010-10-22|title=A multi-level study of recombinant Pichia pastoris in different oxygen conditions|url=http://www.biomedcentral.com/1752-0509/4/141|journal=BMC Systems Biology|language=En|volume=4|issue=1|doi=10.1186/1752-0509-4-141|pmc=2987880|pmid=20969759|pages=141}}</ref> This contrasts with the [[pasteur effect]], which is the inhibition of fermentation in the presence of oxygen, and observed in most organisms.<ref name=":1" />
The evolution of aerobic fermentation likely involved multiple successive molecular steps,<ref name=":1" /> which included the expansion of hexose transporter genes,<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Lin|first=Zhenguo|last2=Li|first2=Wen-Hsiung|date=2011-01-01|title=Expansion of Hexose Transporter Genes Was Associated with the Evolution of Aerobic Fermentation in Yeasts|url=http://mbe.oxfordjournals.org/content/28/1/131|journal=Molecular Biology and Evolution|language=en|volume=28|issue=1|pages=131–142|doi=10.1093/molbev/msq184|issn=0737-4038|pmc=3002240|pmid=20660490}}</ref> [[Copy-number variation|copy number variation]] (CNV)<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Conant|first=Gavin C|last2=Wolfe|first2=Kenneth H|date=2007-01-01|title=Increased glycolytic flux as an outcome of whole-genome duplication in yeast|url=http://msb.embopress.org/cgi/doi/10.1038/msb4100170|journal=Molecular Systems Biology|language=en|volume=3|doi=10.1038/msb4100170|pmc=1943425|pmid=17667951}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Thomson|first=J Michael|last2=Gaucher|first2=Eric A|last3=Burgan|first3=Michelle F|last4=Kee|first4=Danny W De|last5=Li|first5=Tang|last6=Aris|first6=John P|last7=Benner|first7=Steven A|title=Resurrecting ancestral alcohol dehydrogenases from yeast|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/ng1553|journal=Nature Genetics|volume=37|issue=6|pages=630–635|doi=10.1038/ng1553|pmc=3618678|pmid=15864308}}</ref> and differential expression in metabolic genes, and regulatory reprogramming.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Lin|first=Zhenguo|last2=Li|first2=Wen-Hsiung|date=2011-04-01|title=The Evolution of Aerobic Fermentation in Schizosaccharomyces pombe Was Associated with Regulatory Reprogramming but not Nucleosome Reorganization|url=http://mbe.oxfordjournals.org/content/28/4/1407|journal=Molecular Biology and Evolution|language=en|volume=28|issue=4|pages=1407–1413|doi=10.1093/molbev/msq324|issn=0737-4038|pmc=3058771|pmid=21127171}}</ref> Research is still needed to fully understand the genomic basis of this complex phenomenon. Many crabtree-positive yeast species are used for their fermentation ability in industrial processes in the production of wine, beer, sake, bread, and bioethanol.<ref name=":17"/> Through [[domestication]], these yeast species have evolved, often through [[artificial selection]], to better fit their environment.<ref name=":17"/> Strains evolved through mechanisms that include interspecific [[Hybrid (biology)|hybridization]],<ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|last=Libkind|first=Diego|last2=Hittinger|first2=Chris Todd|last3=Valério|first3=Elisabete|last4=Gonçalves|first4=Carla|last5=Dover|first5=Jim|last6=Johnston|first6=Mark|last7=Gonçalves|first7=Paula|last8=Sampaio|first8=José Paulo|date=2011-08-30|title=Microbe domestication and the identification of the wild genetic stock of lager-brewing yeast|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/108/35/14539|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=108|issue=35|pages=14539–14544|doi=10.1073/pnas.1105430108|issn=0027-8424|pmc=3167505|pmid=21873232|bibcode=2011PNAS..10814539L}}</ref> [[horizontal gene transfer]] (HGT), [[gene duplication]], pseudogenization, and gene loss.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Gibbons|first=John G|last2=Rinker|first2=David C|title=The genomics of microbial domestication in the fermented food environment|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0959437X15000787|journal=Current Opinion in Genetics & Development|volume=35|pages=1–8|doi=10.1016/j.gde.2015.07.003|pmc=4695309|pmid=26338497}}</ref>
== Origin of Crabtree effect in yeast == Approximately 100 million years ago (mya), within the yeast lineage there was a [[whole genome duplication]] (WGD).<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Wolfe|first=Kenneth H.|title=Origin of the Yeast Whole-Genome Duplication|url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pbio.1002221|journal=PLOS Biology|volume=13|issue=8|doi=10.1371/journal.pbio.1002221|pmc=4529243|pmid=26252643|pages=e1002221}}</ref> A majority of Crabtree-positive yeasts are post-WGD yeasts.<ref name=":3" /> It was believed that the WGD was a mechanism for the development of Crabtree effect in these species due to the duplication of [[alcohol dehydrogenase]] (ADH) encoding genes and hexose transporters.<ref name=":15" /> However, recent evidence has shown that aerobic fermentation originated before the WGD and evolved as a multi-step process, potentially aided by the WGD.<ref name=":15" /> The origin of aerobic fermentation, or the first step, in ''Saccharomyces'' crabtree-positive yeasts likely occurred in the interval between the ability to grow under anaerobic conditions, horizontal transfer of anaerobic DHODase (encoded by URA1 with bacteria), and the loss of respiratory chain Complex I.<ref name=":1" /> A more pronounced Crabtree effect, the second step, likely occurred near the time of the WGD event.<ref name=":1" /> Later evolutionary events that aided in the evolution of aerobic fermentation are better understood and outlined in the Genomic basis of the crabtree effect section.
=== Driving forces === It is believed that a major driving force in the origin of aerobic fermentation was its simultaneous origin with modern fruit (~125 mya).<ref name=":15" /> These fruit provided an abundance of simple sugar food source for microbial communities, including both yeast and bacteria.<ref name=":15" /> Bacteria, at that time, were able to produce biomass at a faster rate than the yeast.<ref name=":15" /> Producing a toxic compound, like ethanol, can slow the growth of bacteria, allowing the yeast to be more competitive.<ref name=":15" /> However, the yeast still had to use a portion of the sugar it consumes to produce ethanol.<ref name=":15" /> Crabtree-positive yeasts also have increased glycolytic flow, or increased uptake of glucose and conversion to pyruvate, which compensates for using a portion of the glucose to produce ethanol rather than biomass.<ref name=":1" /> Therefore, it is believed that the original driving force was to kill competitors.<ref name=":3" /> This is supported by research that determined the kinetic behavior of the ancestral ADH protein, which was found to be optimized to make ethanol, rather than consume it.<ref name=":4" />
Further evolutionary events in the development of aerobic fermentation likely increased the efficiency of this lifestyle, including increased tolerance to ethanol and the repression of the respiratory pathway.<ref name=":3" /> In high sugar environments, ''S. cerevisiae'' outcompetes and dominants all other yeast species, except its closest relative ''[[Saccharomyces paradoxus]]''.<ref name=":16" /> The ability of ''S. cerevisiae'' to dominate in high sugar environments evolved more recently than aerobic fermentation and is dependent on the type of high-sugar environment.<ref name=":16" /> Other yeasts' growth is dependent on the pH and nutrients of the high-sugar environment.<ref name=":16">{{Cite journal|last=Williams|first=Kathryn M.|last2=Liu|first2=Ping|last3=Fay|first3=Justin C.|date=2015-08-01|title=Evolution of ecological dominance of yeast species in high-sugar environments|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/evo.12707/abstract|journal=Evolution|language=en|volume=69|issue=8|pages=2079–2093|doi=10.1111/evo.12707|issn=1558-5646|pmc=4751874|pmid=26087012}}</ref>
== Genomic basis of the crabtree effect == The genomic basis of the crabtree effect is still being investigated, and its evolution likely involved multiple successive molecular steps that increased the efficiency of the lifestyle.
=== Expansion of hexose transporter genes === [[Glucose transporter|Hexose transporters]] (HXT) are a group of proteins that are largely responsible for the uptake of glucose in yeast. In ''S. cerevisiae'', 20 ''HXT'' genes have been identified and 17 encode for glucose transporters (''HXT1-HXT17''), ''GAL2'' encodes for a galactose transporter, and ''SNF3'' and ''RGT2'' encode for glucose sensors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Boles|first=E.|last2=Hollenberg|first2=C. P.|date=1997-08-01|title=The molecular genetics of hexose transport in yeasts|journal=FEMS Microbiology Reviews|volume=21|issue=1|pages=85–111|issn=0168-6445|pmid=9299703|doi=10.1111/j.1574-6976.1997.tb00346.x}}</ref> The number of glucose sensor genes have remained mostly consistent through the budding yeast lineage, however glucose sensors are absent from ''[[Schizosaccharomyces pombe]]''. ''Sch. pombe'' is a Crabtree-positive yeast, which developed aerobic fermentation independently from ''Saccharomyces'' lineage, and detects glucose via the cAMP-signaling pathway.<ref name=":14" /> The number of transporter genes vary significantly between yeast species and has continually increased during the evolution of the ''S. cerevisiae'' lineage. Most of the transporter genes have been generated by tandem duplication, rather than from the WGD. ''Sch. pombe'' also has a high number of transporter genes compared to its close relatives.<ref name=":9" /> Glucose uptake is believed to be a major rate-limiting step in glycolysis and replacing ''S. cerevisiae''<nowiki/>'s ''HXT1-17'' genes with a single chimera ''HXT'' gene results in decreased ethanol production or fully respiratory metabolism.<ref name=":10" /> Thus, having an efficient glucose uptake system appears to be essential to ability of aerobic fermentation.<ref name=":14" /> There is a significant positive correlation between the number of hexose transporter genes and the efficiency of ethanol production.<ref name=":9" />
=== CNV in glycolysis genes === [[File:Ethanol Fermentation english.png|thumb|A scheme of transformation of glucose to alcohol by alcoholic fermentation.]] After a WGD, one of the duplicated gene pair is often lost through fractionation; less than 10% of WGD gene pairs have remained in ''S. cerevisiae'' genome.<ref name=":10" /> A little over half of WGD gene pairs in the [[glycolysis]] reaction pathway were retained in post-WGD species, significantly higher than the overall retention rate.<ref name=":10" /> This has been associated with an increased ability to metabolize glucose into pyruvate, or higher rate of glycolysis.<ref name=":13" /> After glycolysis, pyruvate can either be further broken down by [[pyruvate decarboxylase]] (Pdc) or [[pyruvate dehydrogenase]] (Pdh). The kinetics of the enzymes are such that when pyruvate concentrations are high, due to a high rate of glycolysis, there is increased flux through Pdc and thus the fermentation pathway.<ref name=":10" /> The WGD is believed to have played a beneficial role in the evolution of the Crabtree effect in post-WGD species partially due to this increase in copy number of glycolysis genes.<ref name=":14" />
=== CNV in fermentation genes === The fermentation reaction only involves two steps. Pyruvate is converted to acetaldehyde by Pdc and then acetaldehyde is converted to ethanol by [[alcohol dehydrogenase]] (Adh). There is no significant increase in the number of ''Pdc'' genes in Crabtree-positive compared to Crabtree-negative species and no correlation between number of ''Pdc'' genes and efficiency of fermentation.<ref name=":14">{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-642-55013-3_5|title=Comparative Genomics and Evolutionary Genetics of Yeast Carbon Metabolism|last=Lin|first=Zhenguo|last2=Li|first2=Wen-Hsiung|date=2014-01-01|publisher=Springer Berlin Heidelberg|isbn=9783642550126|editor-last=Piškur|editor-first=Jure|pages=97–120|language=en|editor-last2=Compagno|editor-first2=Concetta}}</ref> There are five ''Adh'' genes in ''S. cerevisiae''.<ref name=":14" /> Adh1 is the major enzyme responsible for catalyzing the fermentation step from acetaldehyde to ethanol.<ref name=":4" /> Adh2 catalyzes the reverse reaction, consuming ethanol and converting it to acetaldehyde.<ref name=":4" /> The ancestral, or original, Adh had a similar function as Adh1 and after a duplication in this gene, Adh2 evolved a lower K<sub>M</sub> for ethanol.<ref name=":4" /> Adh2 is believed to have increased yeast species' tolerance for ethanol and allowed Crabtree-positive species to consume the ethanol they produced after depleting sugars.<ref name=":4" /> However, Adh2 and consumption of ethanol is not essential for aerobic fermentation.<ref name=":4" /> ''Sch. pombe'' and other Crabtree positive species do not have the ''ADH2'' gene and consumes ethanol very poorly.<ref name=":4" />
=== Differential expression === In Crabtree-negative species, respiration related genes are highly expressed in the presence of oxygen. However, when ''S. cerevisiae'' is grown on glucose in aerobic conditions, respiration-related gene expression is repressed. Mitochondrial ribosomal proteins expression is only induced under environmental stress conditions, specifically low glucose availability.<ref name=":14" /> Genes involving mitochondrial energy generation and phosphorylation oxidation, which are involved in respiration, have the largest expression difference between aerobic fermentative yeast species and respiratory species.<ref name=":14" /> In a comparative analysis between ''Sch. pombe'' and ''S. cerevisiae'', both of which evolved aerobic fermentation independently, the expression pattern of these two fermentative yeasts were more similar to each other than a respiratory yeast, ''C. albicans''. However, ''S. cerevisiae'' is evolutionarily closer to ''C. albicans''.<ref name=":5" /> Regulatory rewiring was likely important in the evolution of aerobic fermentation in both lineages.<ref name=":14" />
== Domestication and aerobic fermentation == [[File:Wine Grapes with dusting that contains yeast.jpg|thumb|A close up picture of ripening wine grapes. The light white "dusting" is a film that also contains wild yeasts.]] Aerobic fermentation is also essential for multiple industries, resulting in human domestication of several yeast strains. Beer and other alcoholic beverages, throughout human history, have played a significant role in society through drinking rituals, providing nutrition, medicine, and uncontaminated water.<ref name=":17" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Legras|first=Jean-Luc|last2=Merdinoglu|first2=Didier|last3=Cornuet|first3=Jean-Marie|last4=Karst|first4=Francis|date=2007-05-01|title=Bread, beer and wine: Saccharomyces cerevisiae diversity reflects human history|journal=Molecular Ecology|volume=16|issue=10|pages=2091–2102|doi=10.1111/j.1365-294X.2007.03266.x|issn=0962-1083|pmid=17498234}}</ref> During the domestication process, organisms shift from natural environments that are more variable and complex to simple and stable environments with a constant substrate. This often favors specialization adaptations in domesticated microbes, associated with relaxed selection for non-useful genes in alternative metabolic strategies or pathogenicity.<ref name=":12" /> Domestication might be partially responsible for the traits that promote aerobic fermentation in industrial species. Introgression and HGT is common in ''Saccharomyces'' domesticated strains.<ref name=":12" /> Many commercial wine strains have significant portions of their DNA derived from HGT of non-''Saccharomyces'' species. HGT and introgression are less common in nature than is seen during domestication pressures.<ref name=":12" /> For example, the important industrial yeast strain ''[[Saccharomyces pastorianus]]'', is an interspecies hybrid of ''S. cerevisiae'' and the cold tolerant ''[[Saccharomyces eubayanus|S. eubayanus]].''<ref name=":17"/> This hybrid is commonly used in lager-brewing, which requires slow, low temperature fermentation.<ref name=":17"/>
== Aerobic fermentation in non-yeast species ==
=== Plants === Alcoholic fermentation is often used by plants in anaerobic conditions to produce [[Adenosine triphosphate|ATP]] and regenerate [[NAD+|NAD<sup>+</sup>]] to allow for glycolysis to continue. For most plant tissues, fermentation only occurs in anaerobic conditions, but there are a few exceptions. In the pollen of [[maize]] (''Zea mays'')<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tadege|first=Million|last2=Dupuis|first2=Isabelle|last3=Kuhlemeier|first3=Cris|date=1999-08-01|title=Ethanolic fermentation: new functions for an old pathway|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1360138599014508|journal=Trends in Plant Science|volume=4|issue=8|pages=320–325|doi=10.1016/S1360-1385(99)01450-8}}</ref> and [[tobacco]] (''Nicotiana tabacum'' & ''Nicotiana plumbaginifolia''), the fermentation enzyme ADH is abundant, regardless of the oxygen level. In tobacco pollen, PDC is also highly expressed in this tissue and transcript levels are not influenced by oxygen concentration. Tobacco pollen, similar to Crabtree-positive yeast, perform high levels of fermentation dependent on the sugar supply, and not oxygen availability. In these tissues, respiration and alcoholic fermentation occur simultaneously with high sugar availability.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Tadege|first=M.|last2=Kuhlemeier|first2=C.|date=1997-10-01|title=Aerobic fermentation during tobacco pollen development|journal=Plant Molecular Biology|volume=35|issue=3|pages=343–354|issn=0167-4412|pmid=9349258|doi=10.1023/A:1005837112653}}</ref> Fermentation produces the toxic acetaldehyde and ethanol, that can build up in large quantities during pollen development. It has been hypothesized that acetaldehyde is a pollen factor that causes [[cytoplasmic male sterility]]. Cytoplasmic male sterility is a trait observed in maize, tobacco and other plants in which there is an inability to produce viable pollen. It is believed that this trait might be due to the expression of the fermentation genes, ADH and PDC, a lot earlier on in pollen development than normal and the accumulation of toxic aldehyde.<ref name=":2" />
=== Trypanosomatids === When grown in glucose-rich media, [[Trypanosomatida|trypanosomatid]] parasites degrade glucose via aerobic fermentation.<ref name=":6" /> In this group, this phenomenon is not a pre-adaptation to/or remnant of anaerobic life, shown through their inability to survive in anaerobic conditions.<ref name=":18" /> It is believed that this phenomenon developed due to the capacity for a high glycolytic flux and the high glucose concentrations of their natural environment. The mechanism for repression of respiration in these conditions is not yet known.<ref name=":18">{{Cite journal|last=Bringaud|first=Frédéric|last2=Rivière|first2=Loïc|last3=Coustou|first3=Virginie|date=2006-09-01|title=Energy metabolism of trypanosomatids: Adaptation to available carbon sources|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0166685106001150|journal=Molecular and Biochemical Parasitology|volume=149|issue=1|pages=1–9|doi=10.1016/j.molbiopara.2006.03.017}}</ref>
=== ''E. coli'' mutant === A couple ''Escherichia coli'' mutant strains have been bioengineered to ferment glucose under aerobic conditions.<ref name=":8" /> One group developed the ECOM3 (''E. coli'' cytochrome oxidase mutant) strain by removing three terminal cytochrome oxidases (cydAB, cyoABCD, and cbdAB) to reduce oxygen uptake.<ref name=":8" /> After 60 days of adaptive evolution on glucose media, the strain displayed a mixed phenotype.<ref name=":8" /> In aerobic conditions, some populations' fermentation solely produced lactate, while others did mixed-acid fermentation.<ref name=":8" />[[File:Warburgh Effect.gif|thumb|Myc and HIF-1 regulate glucose metabolism and stimulate the Warburg effect.]]
=== Tumor cells === One of the hallmarks of cancer is altered metabolism or deregulating cellular energetics.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hanahan|first=Douglas|date=4 March 2011|title=Hallmarks of Cancer: The Next Generation|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0092867411001279|journal=Cell|doi=10.1016/j.cell.2011.02.013|pmid=21376230|access-date=|volume=144|pages=646–674}}</ref> Cancers cells often have reprogrammed their glucose metabolism to perform lactic acid fermentation, in the presence of oxygen, rather than send the pyruvate made through glycolysis to the mitochondria. This is referred to as the [[Warburg effect (oncology)|Warburg effect]], and is associated with high consumption of glucose and a high rate of glycolysis.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Warburg|first=Prof Otto|date=1925-03-01|title=über den Stoffwechsel der Carcinomzelle|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF01726151|journal=Klinische Wochenschrift|language=de|volume=4|issue=12|pages=534–536|doi=10.1007/BF01726151|issn=0023-2173}}</ref> ATP production in these cancer cells is often only through the process of glycolysis and pyruvate is broken down by the fermentation process in the cell's cytoplasm. This phenomenon is often seen as counterintuitive, since cancer cells have higher energy demands due to the continued proliferation and respiration produces significantly more ATP than glycolysis alone (fermentation produces no additional ATP). Typically, there is an up-regulation in glucose transporters and enzymes in the glycolysis pathway (also seen in yeast).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Diaz-Ruiz|first=Rodrigo|last2=Rigoulet|first2=Michel|last3=Devin|first3=Anne|title=The Warburg and Crabtree effects: On the origin of cancer cell energy metabolism and of yeast glucose repression|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0005272810006869|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta (BBA) - Bioenergetics|volume=1807|issue=6|pages=568–576|doi=10.1016/j.bbabio.2010.08.010}}</ref> There are many parallel aspects of aerobic fermentation in tumor cells that are also seen in Crabtree-positive yeasts. Further research into the evolution of aerobic fermentation in yeast such as ''S. cerevisiae'' can be a useful model for understanding aerobic fermentation in tumor cells. This has a potential for better understanding cancer and cancer treatments.<ref name=":7" />
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Evolution]] [[Category:Yeasts]] [[Category:Metabolism]]
{{portal bar|Metabolism}}

'''Cap and dividend''' is a [[market economy|market-based]] [[trading system]] which retains the original capping method of [[cap and trade]], but also includes compensation for energy consumers. This [[Financial compensation|compensation]] is to offset the cost of products produced by companies that raise prices to [[consumer]]s as a result of this [[policy]].{{cite journal |first=James K. |last=Boyce |date = August 2009| accessdate=2010-11-30 |title=Cap and Dividend: A State-By-State Analysis |url= http://www.progressive-economics.org/papers/CAP_DIVIDEND_states.pdf}} The process begins with some governments setting aggregate pollution quotas (e.g., for carbon emissions) and selling pollution permits to the public respectively. Polluters are required to buy those credits to match their pollution outputs. Some of the cost producers pay for pollution will result in higher costs for consumers, who as citizens are additionally faced with the environmental costs of the pollution. Under the cap and dividend system, public revenues raised from the sale of pollution credits is rebated to citizens or to consumers as a subsidy for increasing efficiency.{{cite journal |first=Peter |last=Barnes |accessdate=2010-11-30 |title=How cap and dividend works |url= http://www.capanddividend.org/?q=readfirst}} ==Overview== The goal of this type of pseudo-tax is to reduce carbon emission rates. This is similar to the cap-and-trade system, with the main difference being that citizens receive dividend payments financed from [[economic rent|pollution rents]] that are publicly captured, as opposed to leaving the value of pollution [[Privilege (legal ethics)|privileges]] to become financialized as private assets.{{cite journal |first=Peter. |last=Barnes |date = December 2008| accessdate=2010-11-30 |title=Cap and Dividend, Not Trade: Making Polluters Pay |url= http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=cap-and-divident-not-trade}} The dividend payments can also finance the addition of incentives designed to encourage consumers to increase energy efficiency, whereas cap-and-trade does not directly involve the consumer. The Healthy Climate Trust Fund is the agency in the U.S. government who are overseeing the cap-and-dividend policy. They will accomplish this by collecting and distributing the funds from the capping process. ==Definitions== '''''Provided are convenient definitions pertaining to cap-and-dividend:''''' * '''Cap-and-Dividend:'''
Cap-and-[[dividend]] is an approach to reducing [[greenhouse gas]] (GHG) emissions. The concept is simple: a limit or cap is placed on greenhouse gases from certain sources; these sources are required to obtain permits to cover their greenhouse gas emissions and dividends from the sale of the permits are returned directly to consumers through rebates or tax credits to compensate for increased energy costs. The cap is typically placed on 'upstream' sources – like fossil fuel suppliers – to cover the carbon content of the fuels they distribute. Some limited trading may be allowed, but typically only among covered sources.{{cite journal |first=Agricultural Cultural Market Working Group |last=(ACMWG) |year = 2009 | accessdate=2010-11-30 |title=Cap-and-Dividend and Agriculture |url= http://www.agcarbonmarkets.com/documents/ACMWG%20White%20Paper_Cap-and-Dividend%20and%20Ag_Final.pdf}}
For definitions on Cap-and-Trade, see [[emissions trading]] ==History== The history of the cap and trade system is very recent; it was created and is especially relevant in the political world recently. ===Creation=== Little is known about the origin of the idea, but most likely the idea came from multiple sources as an answer to the problems of cap and trade. It was popularized by American entrepreneur [[Peter Barnes (entrepreneur)|Peter Barnes]] and such groups as [[On the Commons]], a network group which promotes environmental, community-related solutions.{{cite journal |first=Eric |last=de Place |date=5 June 2009| accessdate=30 Nov 2010 |title=Van Hollen's Cap and Dividend |url= http://daily.sightline.org/daily_score/archive/2009/05/06/van-hollens-cap-and-dividend | publisher= [[Sightline Institute]]}} ===Van Hollen Cap and Dividend Bill, 2009=== [[Chris Van Hollen]] (D-Md.) put a bill before Congress on April 1, 2009, pertaining to carbon reductions and including the cap and dividend system. The cosponsors of the bill were Rep [[Earl Blumenauer]] [OR-3], Rep [[Lloyd Doggett]] [TX-25], Rep [[Mike Thompson (California politician)|Mike Thompson]] [CA-1], Rep [[Lynn C. Woolsey]] [CA-6].{{cite journal |first=House of|last=Representatives |date = 2009-04-21| accessdate=2010-12-09 |title=Bill Summary & Status, 111th Congress (2009 - 2010), H.R.1862 |url= http://www.thomas.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/D?d111:2:./temp/~bdm3ar:@@@L&summ2=m&%7C/home/LegislativeData.php?n=BSS;c=111|}} '''The goals of the Cap and Dividend Act of 2009 are as follows:''' * ''Set robust, scientifically driven emissions reductions targets at 25 percent below 2005 levels by 2020 and 85 percent below 2005 levels by 2050 for covered emissions.'' * ''Place an upstream compliance obligation on the first seller of [[fossil fuels]] into the U.S. market.'' * ''Auction 100 percent of carbon permits.'' * ''Include Border Adjustment provisions to protect U.S. manufacturers of carbon-intensive goods from imports of carbon-intensive goods originating in countries without comparable climate legislation and assistance for U.S. exporters of carbon-intensive goods to compete effectively in the international marketplace with carbon-intensive goods originating in countries without comparable climate legislation.'' * ''Return 100% of auction proceeds in the form of a monthly Consumer Dividend to every lawful resident of the United States with a valid Social Security number.''{{cite web|title=Van Hollen Introduces the Cap and Dividend Act of 2009|url=http://vanhollen.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=142911|website=archive.is|accessdate=8 February 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121212013946/http://vanhollen.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=142911|archivedate=12 December 2012|df=}} This bill looked to create the Healthy Climate Trust Fund, the potential agency for managing and distributing dividend funds. The status of the bill included a referral to [[House Ways and Means Committee]] on 4/1/2009, then a referral to [[House Energy and Commerce Committee]] also on 4/1/2009, and then on 4/2/2009 a referral to the [[United States House Energy Subcommittee on Energy and Environment]]. The bill was reviewed by the [[United States House Energy Subcommittee on Energy and Environment]] but it didn't pass as an Act.{{cite web|title=H.R. 1862 (111th): Cap and Dividend Act of 2009|url=https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/111/hr1862|website=GovTrack|publisher=Civic Impulse|accessdate=8 February 2017}} ===Van Hollen Healthy Climate and Family Security Bill, 2015=== Congressman Van Hollen again tried to introduce a Cap and Dividend bill in July 2014, but it did not pass as an Act.{{cite web|last1=Trout|first1=Kelly|title=Congressman Chris Van Hollen introduces innovative bill to fight climate change while aiding middle class Americans|url=http://chesapeakeclimate.org/press-releases/congressman-chris-van-hollen-introduces-innovative-bill-to-fight-climate-change-while-aiding-middle-class-americans/|publisher=Chesapeake Climate Action Network|accessdate=8 February 2017}}{{cite web|title=H.R. 1027 (114th): Healthy Climate and Family Security Act of 2015|url=https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/114/hr1027|website=GovTrack|publisher=Civic Impulse|accessdate=8 February 2017}} ===GOP elder statesmen call on Trump, 2017=== Several elder statesmen of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Grand Old Party (GOP)]], namely former [[United States Secretary of State|Secretaries of State]] [[James Baker]] and [[George Shultz]] and former [[United States Secretary of the Treasury|Treasury Secretary]] [[Henry Paulson|Hank Paulson]], co-authored a report with [[Ted Halstead#Climate Leadership Council|Ted Halstead of Climate Leadership Council]]; and economists [[Martin Feldstein]] and [[Greg Mankiw]]; calling upon [[President Trump]] to introduce cap and dividend.{{cite web|last1=[[James Baker|Baker]]|first1=James|last2=[[George Schultz|Schultz]]|first2=George|title=A Conservative Answer to Climate Change|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/a-conservative-answer-to-climate-change-1486512334|website=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|publisher=[[Dow Jones & Company]]|accessdate=8 February 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Milman|first1=Oliver|title=Republican elders call for new national carbon tax to replace federal regulations|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/feb/08/republican-national-carbon-tax-climate-change|accessdate=8 February 2017|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]}}{{cite news|last1=[[Martin Feldstein|Feldstein]]|first1=Martin|last2=[[Greg Mankiw|Mankiw]]|first2=Greg|last3=[[Ted Halstead|Halstead]]|first3=Ted|title=A Conservative Case for Climate Action|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/08/opinion/a-conservative-case-for-climate-action.html|accessdate=8 February 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|date=8 February 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Crooks|first1=Ed|title=Republican Grandees Make Case for US Emissions Tax|url=https://www.ft.com/content/d8c2ff78-edcf-11e6-ba01-119a44939bb6|accessdate=8 February 2017|work=[[The Financial Times]]|publisher=[[The Nikkei]]}} Mankiw was interviewed about the use of a carbon tax in the 2016 [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] documentary ''[[Before the Flood (film)|Before the Flood]]''. ==Economy== Cap and dividend, like cap and trade, would have had a direct impact on the [[economy]]. With a policy like this it will affect not only the major companies that will be taxed but also every household through a chain reaction of product price increases. There will be variations on how much of an impact this policy would have on different geographical areas based on population and how industrialized the area is.{{cite journal |first=Peter |last=Barnes | accessdate=2010-12-03 |title=How Cap and Dividend Works |url=http://www.capanddividend.org/?q=readfirst}} ===Effect on companies=== Caps will be placed on carbon emissions and every company that use carbon-based fuel to produce some sort of product will have to buy carbon permits. In the cap and dividend policy, every company will have to buy a carbon permit and this differs from the cap and trade policy because there will be no permits given away for free. The permits, collected by the government, will then be used to account for the dividends given back to the people. However, because of the permits' cost, the companies will be forced to raise the prices of their products so they can still make profit.{{cite journal |first=James K. |last=Boyce |date = 1 November 2007| accessdate=8 February 2017 |title=Cap and Dividend: How to Curb Global Warming While Protecting the Incomes of American Families |url=http://scholarworks.umass.edu/peri_workingpapers/108/}} The price increase will be felt by all customers of these various products. ===Effect on households=== The cost of everything made using carbon-based fuels will increase and will be felt by everyone. However, the people most affected by the price increases are the people emitting more carbon. For example: Someone that drives a Hummer is going to have to buy more gas, which the price is increased as well, than a family that drives a fuel-efficient car. Every month the government will automatically send a dividend to offset the cost of the high prices. The people that conserve the most and produced the least amount of carbon emissions will get a bigger dividend than a person who has been producing a large amount of carbon emissions. ==Comparison to Cap and Dividend and other Policies== There have been numerous ideas and attempts to reduce the amount of carbon emissions. Policies have been proposed and rejected. One of the policies that has been actually used is known as the cap and trade system. It is currently being used in Europe and has influenced the people living there. There are several differences between cap and trade and cap and dividend that ultimately define each of them. A cap is placed on carbon emissions and green house gas (GHG) emissions in both policies. Based on the caps there are carbon emission permits that give the companies the ability to produce more carbon emissions then the cap would permit. These permits are auctioned off to different companies. In the cap and trade system only a set amount are auctioned off and the rest are given away for free. In the cap and dividend system all the permits are auctioned off. In both systems the cost of buying the permits will increase the price of the product made by the companies; oil, electric, and products that make carbon emissions. The thought process behind this is to dissuade the purchase of mass quantities of these products i.e. less carbon/GHG emissions. While the cap and trade system uses the high prices to control the amount of carbon emissions they do not provide a good incentive to limit carbon emission. Cap and dividend uses the dividends to reward the people that conserve the most. This will benefit the poor the most because of their living situations and this is found to be a problem with lots of people critiquing the policy. ==See also== * [[ecotax]] * [[Fee and dividend]] * [[pigovian tax]] * [[cap and share]] * [[ecological economics]] * [[georgism]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==See also== *[[Fee and dividend]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Cap and dividend}} [[Category:Economics and climate change]] [[Category:Energy policy]] [[Category:Emissions trading]]

revision.comment: /* History */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Journal of animal science → Journal of Animal Science
revision.text:
{{For|the compensatory growth of organs|Compensatory growth (organ)}}
[[File:Compensatory Growth.jpg|thumb|400px|Representation of compensatory growth]]
'''Compensatory growth''', known as '''catch-up growth''' and '''compensatory gain''', is an accelerated growth of an organism following a period of slowed development, particularly as a result of [[nutrient]] deprivation.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002">{{cite book|author1=David E. Gerrard|author2=Alan L. Grant|title=Principles of Animal Growth and Development|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oZbbxMdGJBEC&pg=PA204|accessdate=5 June 2011|date=September 2002|publisher=Kendall Hunt|isbn=978-0-7872-9147-1|pages=204–208}}</ref><ref name="LawrenceFowler2002">{{cite book|author1=Tony Leonard John Lawrence|author2=V. R. Fowler|title=Growth of farm animals|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6YycK_V2fJQC&pg=PA229|accessdate=6 June 2011|date=November 2002|publisher=CABI|isbn=978-0-85199-484-0|pages=229–254}}</ref> The growth may be with respect to weight or length (or height in humans).<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/><ref name="CG9FullGuideline"/><ref name="pediatrics"/><ref name="Estrogen production and action"/><ref name="The genetic basis of human height : the role of estrogen"/><ref name="Anorexia nervosa may not stunt growth, short term"/><ref name="Effect of anorexia nervosa on linear growth"/> For example, oftentimes the body weights of animals who experience nutritional restriction will over time become similar to those of animals who did not experience such stress.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/> It is possible for high compensatory growth rates to result in overcompensation, where the organism exceeds normal weight and often has excessive fat deposition.<ref name="fundamentals of modern agriculture">{{cite book|title=fundamentals of modern agriculture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EqkOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA279|accessdate=6 June 2011|publisher=Taylor & Francis|pages=279–280|id=GGKEY:BP74C846RC5}}</ref>
An organism can recover to normal weight without additional time.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/> Sometimes when the nutrient restriction is severe, the growth period is extended to reach the normal weight.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/> If the nutrient restriction is severe enough, the organism may have permanent [[stunted growth]] where it does not ever reach normal weight.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/> Usually in animals, complete recovery from [[carbohydrate]] and [[protein]] restriction occurs.<ref name="fundamentals of modern agriculture"/>
Compensatory growth has been observed in a number of organisms including [[human]]s,<ref name="CG9FullGuideline"/><ref name="pediatrics"/><ref name="Estrogen production and action"/><ref name="The genetic basis of human height : the role of estrogen"/><ref name="Anorexia nervosa may not stunt growth, short term"/><ref name="Effect of anorexia nervosa on linear growth"/> other species of [[mammal]]s,<ref name=Wilson>{{Cite journal | last1 = Wilson | first1 = P. | last2 = Osbourn | first2 = D. | title = Compensatory growth after undernutrition in mammals and birds | journal = Biological Reviews of the Cambridge Philosophical Society | volume = 35 | pages = 324–363 | year = 1960 | pmid = 13785698 }}</ref> [[bird]]s,<ref name=Wilson/> [[reptile]]s,<ref name=Radder>{{Cite journal | last1 = Radder | first1 = R. S. | last2 = Warner | first2 = D. A. | last3 = Shine | first3 = R. | title = Compensating for a bad start: Catch-up growth in juvenile lizards (Amphibolurus muricatus, agamidae) | doi = 10.1002/jez.403 | journal = Journal of Experimental Zoology Part A: Ecological Genetics and Physiology | volume = 307A | issue = 9 | pages = 500–508 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17620280 }}</ref> [[fish]],<ref name="Diana2004">{{cite book|author=James S. Diana|title=Biology and ecology of fishes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yMzwAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=6 June 2011|year=2004|publisher=Biological Sciences Press, a Division of Cooper Pub. Group|isbn=978-1-884125-98-0|page=66}}</ref><ref name="Turkmen et al., 2012">{{cite journal|last1=Turkmen|first1=Serhat|title=Compensatory growth response of European sea bass (Dicentrarchus labrax L.) under cycled starvation and restricted feeding rate|journal=Aquaculture Research|date=2012|issue=43|pages=1643–1650}}</ref> [[plant]]s (especially [[grass]]es and young tree [[seedling]]s and [[sapling]]s),<ref name="OrcuttNilsen2000">{{cite book|author1=David M. Orcutt|author2=Erik T. Nilsen|title=The Physiology of Plants Under Stress: Soil and biotic factors|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zDIOVVEQEfcC&pg=PA277|accessdate=6 June 2011|year=2000|publisher=John Wiley and Sons|isbn=978-0-471-17008-2|pages=277–278}}</ref> [[fungi]],<ref name=Bretherton>{{Cite journal | last1 = Bretherton | first1 = S. | last2 = Tordoff | first2 = G. M. | last3 = Jones | first3 = T. H. | last4 = Boddy | first4 = L. | title = Compensatory growth of Phanerochaete velutina mycelial systems grazed by Folsomia candida (Collembola) | doi = 10.1111/j.1574-6941.2006.00149.x | journal = FEMS Microbiology Ecology | volume = 58 | issue = 1 | pages = 33–40 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16958906 }}</ref> [[microbe]]s,<ref name=Mikola>{{citation |author=Mikola J. |author2=H. Setala |last-author-amp=yes |year=1998 |title=No evidence of tropic cascades in an experimental microbial-based food web |journal=Ecology |volume=79 |pages=153–164 |doi=10.2307/176871}}</ref> and [[Eastern Forktail|damselflies]].<ref name=Dmitriew>{{Cite journal | last1 = Dmitriew | first1 = C. | last2 = Rowe | first2 = L. | doi = 10.1007/s00442-004-1712-2 | title = Resource limitation, predation risk and compensatory growth in a damselfly | journal = Oecologia | volume = 142 | issue = 1 | pages = 150–154 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15372227 }}</ref>
==History== In 1911, Hans Aron performed the earliest study of growth after periods of undernourishment.<ref name="HenryUlijaszek1996">{{cite book|author1=C. J. K. Henry|author2=Stanley J. Ulijaszek|title=Long-term consequences of early environment: growth, development, and the lifespan developmental perspective|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=66JbrqPjINgC&pg=PA128|accessdate=6 June 2011|year=1996|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-47108-4|pages=124–138}}</ref> He underfed a dog and found that it still had the capacity to rapidly gain weight, though it did not reach the final weight of a dog that was fed normally.<ref name="HenryUlijaszek1996"/><ref name=Aron>{{cite journal|last=Aron|first=H.|year=1911 |title=Nutrition and growth|journal=Philippine Journal of Sciences, Section B (Medical Science) |volume=6|pages=1–52}}</ref> In 1915, Osborne and Mendel were the first to demonstrate that rats fed after growth restriction had an accelerated growth rate.<ref name=Wilson/><ref name="HenryUlijaszek1996"/><ref name=Osborne>{{cite journal|last1= Osborne|first1=T.B.|last2= Mendel |first2=L. B.|year=1915 |title=The resumption of growth after long continued failure to grow|journal=The Journal of Biological Chemistry|volume=23|pages=439–454}}</ref> In 1945, Brody developed the idea of “homoestasis of growth” in the book ''Bioenergetics and Growth''.<ref name=Wilson/><ref name="HenryUlijaszek1996"/><ref name="Brody">{{cite book|author=S. Brody |title= Bioenergetics and Growth|year=1945|publisher= Reinhold }}</ref> In 1955, Verle Bohman was the first to use the term “compensatory growth” in an article pertaining to [[beef cattle]].<ref name=Wilson/><ref name=Bohman>{{cite journal |last=Bohman |first=V. R. |year=1955 |title= Compensatory Growth of Beef Cattle: The Effect of Hay Maturity |journal= Journal of Animal Science |volume=14 |issue=1 |pages= 249–255 }}</ref>
==Mechanism== In animals, [[Homeostasis|homeostatic]] and [[Homeorhesis|homeorhetic]] processes are involved in the abnormally high growth rates.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/> Homeostatic processes usually affect compensatory growth in the short term, whereas homeorhetic processes usually have a long-term effect.<ref name="LawrenceFowler2002"/>
The exact biological mechanisms for compensatory growth are poorly understood, though it is clear that in some animals the [[endocrine system]] is involved in the [[metabolism]] and nutrient partitioning in the tissues.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/><ref name="Scanes2003">{{cite book|author=C. G. Scanes|title=Biology of growth of domestic animals|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R4Qau0BMeoIC&pg=PA352|accessdate=6 June 2011|date=24 April 2003|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|isbn=978-0-8138-2906-7|page=352}}</ref> First, during nutrient starvation, a reduction of [[Basal animal metabolic rate|basal metabolism]] takes place.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/><ref name="Scanes2003"/> The gut tissues are the first tissues to be reduced in weight and activity.<ref name="Scanes2003"/> Then, during the realimentation (re-feeding) phase, an increase in feeding enables more dietary protein and energy to be contributed for tissue growth instead of basal metabolism.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/> The gut tissues are the first to increase in weight, followed by muscle tissue and finally adipose tissue.<ref name="Scanes2003"/>
==Studies of growth in anorexic human patients== [[Anorexia nervosa]] can have serious implications if its duration and severity are significant and if onset occurs before the completion of growth, pubertal maturation or prior to attaining peak bone mass.<ref name="medical">{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/(SICI)1099-0968(200003)8:2<170::AID-ERV338>3.0.CO;2-Y|title=Medical complications of anorexia nervosa in children and young adolescents|year=2000|last1=Nicholls|first1=Dasha|last2=Stanhope|first2=Richard|journal=European Eating Disorders Review|volume=8|issue=2|pages=170–180}} </ref> Both height gain and pubertal development are dependent on the release of growth hormone and gonadotrophins (LH and FSH) from the pituitary gland. Suppression of gonadotropins in patients with anorexia nervosa has been frequently documented.<ref name="medical"/> In some cases, especially where onset is pre-pubertal, physical consequences such as stunted growth and pubertal delay are usually fully reversible.<ref name="CG9FullGuideline">{{cite journal|journal=National Collaborating Centre for Mental Health|year=2004 |title=Core interventions in the treatment and management of anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa and related eating disorders |url=http://www.nice.org.uk/nicemedia/pdf/CG9FullGuideline.pdf}}</ref> Height potential is normally preserved if the duration and severity of anorexia nervosa are not significant and/or if the illness is accompanied with delayed bone age (especially prior to a bone age of approximately 15 years), as hypogonadism may negate the deleterious effects of undernutrition on stature by allowing for a longer duration of growth compared to controls.<ref name="pediatrics">{{Cite journal | last1 = Prabhakaran | first1 = R. | last2 = Misra | first2 = M. | last3 = Miller | first3 = K. K. | last4 = Kruczek | first4 = K. | last5 = Sundaralingam | first5 = S. | last6 = Herzog | first6 = D. B. | last7 = Katzman | first7 = D. K. | last8 = Klibanski | first8 = A. | doi = 10.1542/peds.2007-2820 | title = Determinants of Height in Adolescent Girls with Anorexia Nervosa | journal = Pediatrics | volume = 121 | issue = 6 | pages = e1517–e1523 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18519455 | pmc = }}</ref> In such cases, appropriate early treatment can preserve height potential and may even help to increase it in some post-anorexic subjects due to the aforementioned reasons in addition to factors such as long-term reduced estrogen-producing [[adipose tissue]] levels compared to premorbid levels.<ref name="Estrogen production and action">{{cite journal |vauthors=Nelson LR, Bulun SE |title=Estrogen production and action |journal=J. Am. Acad. Dermatol. |volume=45 |issue=3 Suppl |pages=S116–24 |year=2001 |pmid=11511861 |doi= 10.1067/mjd.2001.117432}}</ref><ref name="The genetic basis of human height : the role of estrogen">{{cite journal |author=Carter, Shea L.|title=The genetic basis of human height : the role of estrogen |year=2008 |url=http://eprints.qut.edu.au/28390/}}</ref><ref name="Anorexia nervosa may not stunt growth, short term">{{cite web|work=Reuters|date=2008-06-06 |title=Anorexia nervosa may not stunt growth, short term |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2008/06/06/us-anorexia-nervosa-idUSCOL66234120080606}}</ref><ref name="Effect of anorexia nervosa on linear growth">{{cite journal | pmid = 3943254 | volume=25 | title=Effect of anorexia nervosa on linear growth | journal=Clin Pediatr (Phila) | pages=7–12 | last1 = Pfeiffer | first1 = RJ | last2 = Lucas | first2 = AR | last3 = Ilstrup | first3 = DM}}</ref>
==Factors affecting compensatory growth== In 1960, Wilson and Osborne outlined six factors that could affect compensatory growth in a review article.<ref name="LawrenceFowler2002"/><ref name=Wilson/> The importance of each, some, or all of these factors is not well understood.<ref name="fundamentals of modern agriculture"/> These factors are as follows:<ref name="LawrenceFowler2002"/><ref name="fundamentals of modern agriculture"/><ref name=Wilson/> * The nature of the restricted diet * The degree of severity of undernutrition * The duration of the period of undernutrition * The stage of development at the commencement of undernutrition * The relative rate of maturity of the species * The pattern of re-alimenation
Animal factors that can affect compensatory growth may include the maturity level and fat proportion of the animal at the time of nutrient deprivation, the genotype, the gender, and the metabolic changes.<ref name="LawrenceFowler2002"/> The stage of development of the animal when the nutrient restriction occurs greatly affects its body composition.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/>
==See also== *[[Starvation]]
